question: How do I apply for Direct School Admission for Secondary Schools?
answer:
Application for DSA-Sec can be submitted through the online MOE DSA-Sec Portal.
https://www.dsa-is.moe.gov.sg/login/mainstreamapplicant
The application is free-of-charge.
Each P6 student can only submit a total of three (3) DSA choices for all schools and categories offered for DSA. The MOE DSA-Sec Portal is open from 7 May 2024 (11 am) to 3 June 2024 (3 pm).

question: Can my son apply for DSA if he is not studying in an MOE school?
answer:
Singaporean Students
Students who are currently home-schooled must contact MOE to obtain a registration number before applying for DSA.
Returning Singaporeans
Students who are not taking the PSLE should contact MOE to obtain a registration number before applying for DSA. They may take the MOE SPERS for English and Mathematics.
International Students
International students must contact MOE to obtain a registration number before applying for DSA. They would need to take part in the Admissions Exercise for International Students (AEIS) conducted by MOE and be accepted before they can apply for DSA.

question: What are the DSA categories in HCI?
answer:
Bilingualism

question: My son is talented in areas that are not in the DSA categories. How can my son join HCI?
answer: Our range of programmes develop all who join us either via DSA or the post-PSLE posting exercise. We nurture and stretch strengths, interests and passions in all our students.

question: My son is talented in more than one field. Can he apply for more than one DSA category?
answer: Yes. Your son may choose up to two categories for DSA from one school. It will count as two of his three choices. If he is shortlisted for two categories from HCI, arrangements will be made for him to attend interviews in both categories on 27 July 2024.

question: My son has talents and achievements in other areas (e.g. triathlon, dance, golf). Will these be considered?
answer: Our focus during the DSA exercise is to spot and develop specific talents that are related to our DSA categories. If there is information you deem relevant, please include them in the section “Non School-based Awards and Achievements”. Each applicant is restricted to 10 entries in this section.

question: After submitting my son’s DSA application, what is the process like?
answer:
Only shortlisted students will be invited for interviews and selection tests.
Sports trials will also be conducted for applicants in the DSA (Sports) category.

question: How should I prepare my son for the DSA Interview? What is the DSA interview panel looking out for?
answer:
Candidates should be comfortable speaking up in a group interview and should ideally be bilingually conversant. Each category has the associated approaches relevant to the talent domain. The interview panel is primarily looking out for a good fit with HCI’s culture and values and our Integrated Programme.

question: Will a sports coach be an influence in the DSA process?
answer: All coaches have to declare if their students (private or otherwise) are participating in the HCI DSA Exercise. All assessments will be considered fairly and objectively during our sports trials.

question: Can HCI reschedule my son’s interview in the event of a clash with another school’s DSA interview/trials?
answer: HCI will conduct all interviews on 27 July 2024.

question: If my son is unable to attend his DSA interview for genuine medical or official reasons, will HCI be able to reschedule his interview?
answer: For students who are medically certified to be unwell on 27 July 2024, rescheduling the in-person selection may be arranged where possible.

question: How many places does HCI offer for students admitted via DSA?
answer:
MOE manages the admission details. On average, IP schools admit 30% of their Sec One cohort via DSA. There are no exact percentages for admission via each DSA category. This will depend on the range of talents who apply to each category.

question: What happens if my son receives
answer:
(a) Confirmed Offer (CO) from HCI?
Applicants with a Confirmed Offer are guaranteed a place in HCI, provided that they indicate the school as one of their preferences during the School Preference Exercise, and that they qualify for the Express academic course (AL<=22).
(b) Waitlist (WL) from HCI?
Applicants with a Waitlist Offer should place HCI as their first choice during the School Preference Exercise to better their chances of entry.

question: Must my son stay in the same Sports CCA if he joins HCI through DSA (Sports)?
answer:
Taking up a DSA offer is a serious commitment on the part of the student athlete.
Athletes will be required to commit their best efforts to the sport for their entire time at HCI barring exceptional circumstances.
Teachers and coaches at Hwa Chong will be similarly committed to the development of the student. All athletes will participate in regular, systematic and intensive training throughout the year in order to give them the best chance to excel.
Family support is pivotal for a DSA athlete to succeed in any school system. Parents will be important partners to support, engage and motivate their sons in their sporting endeavours.

question: What avenues of support are available to an athlete who cannot cope with training?
answer:
Many factors may impinge on performance. Issues such as academic pressures, stress and injury will be comprehensively addressed by the teachers, coaches, sport physiologists and, when necessary, school counsellors.
Student athletes may explore transferring across sports teams to tap on their natural talent in another sport. Such a measure is only taken as a last resort.

question: Are DSA (Academic) students required to join a specific CCA?
answer:
CCA requirements vary among DSA categories.
Applicants who enter HCI via DSA-Infocomm are required to enrol in the Infocomm and Robotics Club as their CCA. Applicants who enter HCI via DSA-Chinese Language are strongly encouraged to join the Chinese Society.
Entrants from other DSA (Academic) categories can select CCAs out of their own interests and passions beyond the classroom setting.

question: What are the commitments of a DSA (Academic) student?
answer: It is crucial for all students to start their secondary school journey well. Once the fundamental foundations are in progress, students will be guided with the range of opportunities to stretch their talents in their DSA area.

question: What commitments must a DSA (Leadership) student fulfil, and for how long? Will he be assigned a specific CCA?
answer:
Students enrolling at HCI through DSA (Leadership) will be groomed to take on leadership positions.They may start off with positions in the Class Management Committee, and may progress to other student leadership platforms. These include the Consortium Councils, High School Council, CCA Leadership and College Students’ Council, among others. They are not allocated to any specific CCA by default.

question: Will the programmes at HCI develop my son’s future-readiness?
answer:
Certainly. Students will delve deeper in their areas of talent, such as engaging in deep research and by broadening their perspectives through competitions and collaboration with industry experts. Our graduates have gone on to emerge as leaders in their respective fields in research, industry and government.
More information on our programmes:
https://www.hci.edu.sg/high-school/academic-prog/

question: If my son enters HCI through DSA in a particular academic category, will he still be developed in other areas?
answer: Yes. While your son will be specially developed in his area of talent, we aim to develop every student holistically. He will not be denied opportunities in other areas. In fact, he will be encouraged to broaden his perspectives.

question: Are the DSA talents from the same category grouped into the same classes?
answer:
Where relevant, students will be banded into classes within curriculum time. There may also be other opportunities and activities after school.

question: What is the ideal HCI student ?
answer:
Our vision is to empower our students to live with passion and lead with compassion, and we aim to nurture them to serve the nation by being leaders in Research, Industry and Government.
We nurture students to live by the core values of 自 强 不 息 (tireless self-improvement with tenacity, innovation and passion), 己 立 立 人, 己 达 达 人 (WIN – WIN) and 饮 水 思 源 (remembering our roots and honouring our benefactors). Our students must remember that all their achievements come from the synergised commitment from many who care for them.

question: How are the students grouped into the various consortia?
answer: Banded arrangements are considered in class placement. Any class banding is to cater to the specific learning needs of our students.  The consortium-system is conceptualised for holistic nurturing of all our students and have equal standing.

question: How are CCAs assigned to students?
answer: Students will have the chance to try out different CCAs at the start of the year. Students will also be asked to rank their CCA choices before they are eventually assigned one. Students who display interest and aptitude in a particular CCA will be shortlisted for further trials.

question: How often do students attend CCA training? Are DSA (Sports) students expected to attend more training sessions?
answer:
The level of commitment expected from all students is the same between DSA and Non-DSA students. The number of CCA training sessions varies across CCAs and depends on the period of the CCA’s competitions.

question: What are HCI’s school fees?
answer: For details, please refer to the information on our school website at https://www.hci.edu.sg/high-school/financial-info/

question: Will there be scholarships and subsidies offered to students?
answer: No deserving Singaporean student will be denied entry to HCI because of financial reasons. There are a range of subsidies and scholarships available for those who are financially needy. Financial information is available here - https://www.hci.edu.sg/high-school/financial-info/

question: How big will the 2025 HCI Sec One cohort be?
answer: The size of our Sec One cohort is dependent on MOE’s allocation. The number has been approximately 400 in recent years. This figure is likely to remain stable in the near future.

question: What is the PSLE Achievement Level Cut-Off Point (AL COP) to enter HCI (non-DSA)?
answer:
The score range for entry into HCI in 2024 was 4(D)-7(D)*. Schools’ score ranges may vary from year to year, depending on the cohort’s PSLE results and their school choices in the Posting Exercise.
*HCL Grade: (D) = Distinction, (M) = Merit
The HCL grades of the first and last student admitted into SAP schools are reflected in parenthesis.

question: Are the classrooms in Hwa Chong air-conditioned?
answer: The Upper Secondary classrooms are air-conditioned.

question: How long does it take to walk from Tan Kah Kee MRT Station to the High School Section? Is it sheltered all the way?
answer: The fully-sheltered walk from Tan Kah Kee MRT Station to the High School Section takes about 10 minutes. The alternative partly-sheltered walking route takes about 7 minutes.

question: What are typical school hours like?
answer:
Typical school hours for lower secondary students are from 7.30am to 1.30pm.
Upper Secondary students have afternoon lessons on certain days, and students’ timetable vary across programmes.
CCA sessions typically end around 5.30pm.

question: How long are recess and lunch breaks?
answer: The duration of recess is 30 minutes. On days with afternoon lessons or other activities, there is also a lunch break that lasts 60 minutes.

question: Is a laptop/tablet compulsory for all students? If so, does the school arrange any laptop/tablet sales for students, or are they given the required specifications to buy one on their own?
answer: At MOE’s Committee of Supply Debate in March 2020, MOE introduced the National Digital Literacy Programme (NDLP) for all schools and Institutes of Higher Learning to help students strengthen their digital literacy. Under NDLP, every secondary school student will own a school-prescribed Personal Learning Device (PLD). The PLD is essential for blended learning, whereby students will need the PLD for learning in class and during home-based learning. The PLD will also be used in tandem with the national e-learning platform – the Singapore Student Learning Space  – as well as other educational technology to personalise and enhance students’ learning. This will also enable students to acquire digital skills and apply these skills as they navigate an increasingly digitalised world.

question: When will Secondary One students receive their PLDs?
answer: The school will make arrangements for the purchase of PLD by the new Sec 1 cohort so all students will have a PLD to bring along to school for learning by Term 2 of each academic year. Parents have a choice to purchase a PLD through the school or purchase one that is compatible with the school-recommended PLD from other external vendors. Singaporeans can use Edusave to pay for the PLD that is purchased through the school. More details will be available once your son joins HCI.

question: Where are 3rd language lessons conducted?
answer:
Malay language lessons are conducted in HCI. For other 3rd language lessons, they will be held at the MOE Language Centres at either Newton or Bishan.
